results.title: The Solar sea
results.creator_credit: Georgann Kane, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Planet earth”.
Our sun is a star that powers the earth. it gives life, creates weather, warms the oceans, the land and even the ice. This program looks at the history of man’s involvement with the sun, and with the latest research into such phenomena as sun spots, solar flares and the solar wind, using infra-red and x-ray satellite photography to illustrate the immense forces which ultimately control the future of the earth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Georgann Kane, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED

results.title: Gifts from the earth
results.creator_credit: Theodore Thomas, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Planet earth”.
There are only 150 sites world wide for the minerals essential to man and in the past decade we have been made aware that the earth is a closed system and its resources are finite. This program looks at the challenge of finding new sources of these minerals and the highly sophisticated technologies which are employed to do so, and also at how the resources are created.

results.title: Tales from other worlds
results.creator_credit: Robin Bates, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Planet earth”.
Voyages to other planets have shown us that earth is unique. The question now is why? Through the use of little-seen footage shot in space, this program attempts to answer questions such as why there is no life on Mars and Venus, why the dinosaurs disappeared, whether earth has been bombarded by meteorites in the past. A fascinating look at the formation of the planets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin Bates, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED

results.title: The Climate puzzle
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Planet earth”.
Scientists tell us that no human beings have ever experienced the earth’s “normal climate”. Civilisation has flourished in a narrow window between vast ice ages. When will climate change again and why? Are we entering a new ice age, or will the current global warming trend from the greenhouse effect, hold off the inevitable?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregory Andorfer, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED

results.title: The Blue planet
results.creator_credit: Theodore Thomas, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Planet earth”.
The oceans may still be the last great unexplored frontier on earth. Computers and satellite photography help to illustrate the latest research into the links between ocean currents and the weather, their effect on the creatures who live in the sea and the discovery of hot springs and seafloor spreading on the ocean floor.

results.title: The Living machine
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Planet earth”.
Plate tectonics, one of the most important discoveries of the 20th Century is explored with world-renowned scientists on location. The program describes the first discoveries and what recent research has taught us about the creation and continuing shaping of the earth.

results.title: Mike Mulligan and his steam shovel
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
An iconographic film using the pictures and text of Virginia Lee Burton’s story of the steam shovel that defied obsolescence by becoming the furnace in the Popperville Town Hall. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Hush little baby (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
Family life in 18th century America is pictured with authenticity and charm in this enchanting animated rendition of the traditional folk lullaby. Illustrated and based on the book by Aliki.

results.title: The Circus baby
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Picture Book Parade”.
Tells the story of the mother elephant who learns that she should not try to get her baby to act like a human. Iconographic animation. From the book written and illustrated by Maud and Miska Petersham. Suitable for lower primary level.
